553.title: Bayes' rule: Definition
553.text:
Bayes' rule is a tool for updating your beliefs in the face of evidence, which can help you make better predictions about the world. To quote [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superforecasting _Superforecasting_], a book about people who are inordinately good at predicting the future: > The superforecasters are a numerate bunch: many know about Bayes' theorem and could deploy it if they felt it was worth the trouble. But they rarely crunch the numbers so explicitly. What matters far more to the superforecasters than Bayes' theorem is Bayes' core insight of gradually getting closer to the truth by constantly updating in proportion to the weight of the evidence.

— Philip Tetlock and Dan Gardner, _Superforecasting_ [toc:] ## [1y9 Notation] In much of what follows, we'll use the following [1y9 notation]: - Let the hypotheses being considered be $H_1$ and $H_2$. - Let the evidence observed be $e_0.$ - Let $\mathbb P(H_i)$ denote the [1rm prior probability] of $H_i$ before observing the evidence. - Let the [1rj conditional probability] $\mathbb P(e_0\mid H_i)$ denote the [1rq likelihood] of observing evidence $e_0$ assuming $H_i$ to be true. - Let the [1rj conditional probability] $\mathbb P(H_i\mid e_0)$ denote the [1rp posterior probability] of $H_i$ after observing $e_0.$ ## [1x5 Odds]/[1zm proportional] form Bayes' rule in the [1x5 odds form] or [1zm proportional form] states: $$\dfrac{\mathbb P(H_1)}{\mathbb P(H_2)} \times \dfrac{\mathbb P(e_0\mid H_1)}{\mathbb P(e_0\mid H_2)} = \dfrac{\mathbb P(H_1\mid e_0)}{\mathbb P(H_2\mid e_0)}$$ In other words, the [1rm prior] [1rb odds] times the [1rq likelihood ratio] yield the [1rp posterior] odds. [1rk Normalizing] these odds will then yield the posterior probabilities. In [1zm other other words]: If you initially think $h_i$ is $\alpha$ times as probable as $h_k$, and then see evidence that you're $\beta$ times as likely to see if $h_i$ is true as if $h_k$ is true, you should update to thinking that $h_i$ is $\alpha \cdot \beta$ times as probable as $h_k.$ Suppose that Professor Plum and Miss Scarlet are two suspects in a murder, and that we start out thinking that Professor Plum is twice as likely to have committed the murder as Miss Scarlet ([1rm prior] [1rb odds] of 2 : 1). We then discover that the victim was poisoned. We think that Professor Plum is around one-fourth as likely to use poison as Miss Scarlet ([1rq likelihood ratio] of 1 : 4). Then after observing the victim was poisoned, we should think Plum is around half as likely to have committed the murder as Scarlet: $2 \times \dfrac{1}{4} = \dfrac{1}{2}.$ This reflects [1rp posterior] odds of 1 : 2, or a posterior probability of 1/3, that Professor Plum did the deed. ## [1xr Proof] The [1xr proof of Bayes' rule] is by the definition of [1rj conditional probability] $\mathbb P(X\wedge Y) = \mathbb P(X\mid Y) \cdot \mathbb P(Y):$ $$ \dfrac{\mathbb P(H_i)}{\mathbb P(H_j)} \times \dfrac{\mathbb P(e\mid H_i)}{\mathbb P(e\mid H_j)} = \dfrac{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_i)}{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_j)} = \dfrac{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_i) / \mathbb P(e)}{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_j) / \mathbb P(e)} = \dfrac{\mathbb P(H_i\mid e)}{\mathbb P(H_j\mid e)} $$ ## [1zh Log odds form] The [1zh log odds form of Bayes' rule] states: $$\log \left ( \dfrac {\mathbb P(H_i)} {\mathbb P(H_j)} \right ) + \log \left ( \dfrac {\mathbb P(e\mid H_i)} {\mathbb P(e\mid H_j)} \right ) = \log \left ( \dfrac {\mathbb P(H_i\mid e)} {\mathbb P(H_j\mid e)} \right ) $$ E.g.: "A study of Chinese blood donors found that roughly 1 in 100,000 of them had HIV (as determined by a very reliable gold-standard test). The non-gold-standard test used for initial screening had a sensitivity of 99.7% and a specificity of 99.8%, meaning that it was 500 times as likely to return positive for infected as non-infected patients." Then our prior belief is -5 orders of magnitude against HIV, and if we then observe a positive test result, this is evidence of strength +2.7 orders of magnitude for HIV. Our posterior belief is -2.3 orders of magnitude, or odds of less than 1 to a 100, against HIV. In log odds form, the same [22x strength of evidence] (log [1rq likelihood ratio]) always [1zh moves us the same additive distance] along a line representing strength of belief (also in log odds). If we measured distance in probabilities, then the same 2 : 1 likelihood ratio might move us a different distance along the probability line depending on whether we started with prior 10% probability or 50% probability. ## Visualizations Graphical of visualizing Bayes' rule include [1wy frequency diagrams, the waterfall visualization], the [1zm spotlight visualization], the [1zh magnet visualization], and the [1xr Venn diagram for the proof]. ## Examples Examples of Bayes' rule may be found [1wt here]. ## [1zg Multiple hypotheses and updates] The [1x5 odds form of Bayes' rule] works for odds ratios between more than two hypotheses, and applying multiple pieces of evidence. Suppose there's a bathtub full of coins. 1/2 of the coins are "fair" and have a 50% probability of producing heads on each coinflip; 1/3 of the coins produce 25% heads; and 1/6 produce 75% heads. You pull out a coin at random, flip it 3 times, and get the result HTH. You may legitimately calculate: $$\begin{array}{rll} (1/2 : 1/3 : 1/6) \cong & (3 : 2 : 1) & \\ \times & (2 : 1 : 3) & \\ \times & (2 : 3 : 1) & \\ \times & (2 : 1 : 3) & \\ = & (24 : 6 : 9) & \cong (8 : 2 : 3) \end{array}$$ Since multiple pieces of evidence may not be [conditional_independence conditionally independent] from one another, it is important to be aware of the [naive_bayes_assumption Naive Bayes assumption] and whether you are making it. ## [554 Probability form] As a formula for a single probability $\mathbb P(H_i\mid e),$ Bayes' rule states: $$\mathbb P(H_i\mid e) = \dfrac{\mathbb P(e\mid H_i) \cdot \mathbb P(H_i)}{\sum_k \mathbb P(e\mid H_k) \cdot \mathbb P(H_k)}$$ ## [1zj Functional form] In [1zj functional form], Bayes' rule states: $$\mathbb P(\mathbf{H}\mid e) \propto \mathbb P(e\mid \mathbf{H}) \cdot \mathbb P(\mathbf{H}).$$ The posterior probability function over hypotheses given the evidence, is *proportional* to the likelihood function from the evidence to those hypotheses, times the prior probability function over those hypotheses. Since posterior probabilities over [1rd mutually exclusive and exhaustive] possibilities must sum to $1,$ [1rk normalizing] the product of the likelihood function and prior probability function will yield the exact posterior probability function.

1ln.editSummary: alias. note to self: come back and explain new requisites system.
1ln.title: Arbital requisites
1ln.clickbait: To understand a thing you often need to understand some other things.

1lw.title: Mathematics
1lw.clickbait: Mathematics is the study of numbers and other ideal objects that can be described by axioms.

1lz.title: Bayes' rule
1lz.clickbait: Bayes' rule is the core theorem of probability theory saying how to revise our beliefs when we make a new observation.

1rd.title: Mutually exclusive and exhaustive
1rd.clickbait: The condition needed for probabilities to sum to 1

1rf.title: Probability
1rf.clickbait: The degree to which someone believes something, measured on a scale from 0 to 1, allowing us to do math to it.

1rj.title: Conditional probability
1rj.clickbait: The notation for writing "The probability that someone has green eyes, if we know that they have red hair."

1rk.title: Normalization (probability)
1rk.clickbait: That thingy we do to make sure our probabilities sum to 1, when they should sum to 1.

1rm.title: Prior probability
1rm.clickbait: What we believed before seeing the evidence.

1rp.title: Posterior probability
1rp.clickbait: What we believe, after seeing the evidence and doing a Bayesian update.

1rq.title: Relative likelihood
1rq.clickbait: How relatively likely an observation is, given two or more hypotheses, determines the strength and direction of evidence.

1rt.title: Arbital path
1rt.clickbait: Arbital path is a linear sequence of pages tailored specifically to teach a given concept to a user.

1wt.clickbait: Interesting problems solvable by Bayes' rule

1wy.title: Waterfall diagram
1wy.clickbait: Visualizing Bayes' rule as the mixing of probability streams.

1x5.clickbait: The simplest and most easily understandable form of Bayes' rule uses relative odds.

1xr.title: Proof of Bayes' rule
1xr.clickbait: Proofs of Bayes' rule, with graphics

1y9.title: Probability notation for Bayes' rule
1y9.clickbait: The probability notation used in Bayesian reasoning

1zg.title: Bayes' rule: Vector form
1zg.clickbait: For when you want to apply Bayes' rule to lots of evidence and lots of variables, all in one go. (This is more or less how spam filters work.)

1zh.title: Bayes' rule: Log-odds form
1zh.clickbait: A simple transformation of Bayes' rule reveals tools for measuring degree of belief, and strength of evidence.

1zj.clickbait: Bayes' rule for to continuous variables.

553.title: Bayes' rule: Definition
553.text:
Bayes' rule is a tool for updating your beliefs in the face of evidence, which can help you make better predictions about the world. To quote [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superforecasting _Superforecasting_], a book about people who are inordinately good at predicting the future: > The superforecasters are a numerate bunch: many know about Bayes' theorem and could deploy it if they felt it was worth the trouble. But they rarely crunch the numbers so explicitly. What matters far more to the superforecasters than Bayes' theorem is Bayes' core insight of gradually getting closer to the truth by constantly updating in proportion to the weight of the evidence.

— Philip Tetlock and Dan Gardner, _Superforecasting_ [toc:] ## [1y9 Notation] In much of what follows, we'll use the following [1y9 notation]: - Let the hypotheses being considered be $H_1$ and $H_2$. - Let the evidence observed be $e_0.$ - Let $\mathbb P(H_i)$ denote the [1rm prior probability] of $H_i$ before observing the evidence. - Let the [1rj conditional probability] $\mathbb P(e_0\mid H_i)$ denote the [1rq likelihood] of observing evidence $e_0$ assuming $H_i$ to be true. - Let the [1rj conditional probability] $\mathbb P(H_i\mid e_0)$ denote the [1rp posterior probability] of $H_i$ after observing $e_0.$ ## [1x5 Odds]/[1zm proportional] form Bayes' rule in the [1x5 odds form] or [1zm proportional form] states: $$\dfrac{\mathbb P(H_1)}{\mathbb P(H_2)} \times \dfrac{\mathbb P(e_0\mid H_1)}{\mathbb P(e_0\mid H_2)} = \dfrac{\mathbb P(H_1\mid e_0)}{\mathbb P(H_2\mid e_0)}$$ In other words, the [1rm prior] [1rb odds] times the [1rq likelihood ratio] yield the [1rp posterior] odds. [1rk Normalizing] these odds will then yield the posterior probabilities. In [1zm other other words]: If you initially think $h_i$ is $\alpha$ times as probable as $h_k$, and then see evidence that you're $\beta$ times as likely to see if $h_i$ is true as if $h_k$ is true, you should update to thinking that $h_i$ is $\alpha \cdot \beta$ times as probable as $h_k.$ Suppose that Professor Plum and Miss Scarlet are two suspects in a murder, and that we start out thinking that Professor Plum is twice as likely to have committed the murder as Miss Scarlet ([1rm prior] [1rb odds] of 2 : 1). We then discover that the victim was poisoned. We think that Professor Plum is around one-fourth as likely to use poison as Miss Scarlet ([1rq likelihood ratio] of 1 : 4). Then after observing the victim was poisoned, we should think Plum is around half as likely to have committed the murder as Scarlet: $2 \times \dfrac{1}{4} = \dfrac{1}{2}.$ This reflects [1rp posterior] odds of 1 : 2, or a posterior probability of 1/3, that Professor Plum did the deed. ## [1xr Proof] The [1xr proof of Bayes' rule] is by the definition of [1rj conditional probability] $\mathbb P(X\wedge Y) = \mathbb P(X\mid Y) \cdot \mathbb P(Y):$ $$ \dfrac{\mathbb P(H_i)}{\mathbb P(H_j)} \times \dfrac{\mathbb P(e\mid H_i)}{\mathbb P(e\mid H_j)} = \dfrac{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_i)}{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_j)} = \dfrac{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_i) / \mathbb P(e)}{\mathbb P(e \wedge H_j) / \mathbb P(e)} = \dfrac{\mathbb P(H_i\mid e)}{\mathbb P(H_j\mid e)} $$ ## [1zh Log odds form] The [1zh log odds form of Bayes' rule] states: $$\log \left ( \dfrac {\mathbb P(H_i)} {\mathbb P(H_j)} \right ) + \log \left ( \dfrac {\mathbb P(e\mid H_i)} {\mathbb P(e\mid H_j)} \right ) = \log \left ( \dfrac {\mathbb P(H_i\mid e)} {\mathbb P(H_j\mid e)} \right ) $$ E.g.: "A study of Chinese blood donors found that roughly 1 in 100,000 of them had HIV (as determined by a very reliable gold-standard test). The non-gold-standard test used for initial screening had a sensitivity of 99.7% and a specificity of 99.8%, meaning that it was 500 times as likely to return positive for infected as non-infected patients." Then our prior belief is -5 orders of magnitude against HIV, and if we then observe a positive test result, this is evidence of strength +2.7 orders of magnitude for HIV. Our posterior belief is -2.3 orders of magnitude, or odds of less than 1 to a 100, against HIV. In log odds form, the same [22x strength of evidence] (log [1rq likelihood ratio]) always [1zh moves us the same additive distance] along a line representing strength of belief (also in log odds). If we measured distance in probabilities, then the same 2 : 1 likelihood ratio might move us a different distance along the probability line depending on whether we started with prior 10% probability or 50% probability. ## Visualizations Graphical of visualizing Bayes' rule include [1wy frequency diagrams, the waterfall visualization], the [1zm spotlight visualization], the [1zh magnet visualization], and the [1xr Venn diagram for the proof]. ## Examples Examples of Bayes' rule may be found [1wt here]. ## [1zg Multiple hypotheses and updates] The [1x5 odds form of Bayes' rule] works for odds ratios between more than two hypotheses, and applying multiple pieces of evidence. Suppose there's a bathtub full of coins. 1/2 of the coins are "fair" and have a 50% probability of producing heads on each coinflip; 1/3 of the coins produce 25% heads; and 1/6 produce 75% heads. You pull out a coin at random, flip it 3 times, and get the result HTH. You may legitimately calculate: $$\begin{array}{rll} (1/2 : 1/3 : 1/6) \cong & (3 : 2 : 1) & \\ \times & (2 : 1 : 3) & \\ \times & (2 : 3 : 1) & \\ \times & (2 : 1 : 3) & \\ = & (24 : 6 : 9) & \cong (8 : 2 : 3) \end{array}$$ Since multiple pieces of evidence may not be [conditional_independence conditionally independent] from one another, it is important to be aware of the [naive_bayes_assumption Naive Bayes assumption] and whether you are making it. ## [554 Probability form] As a formula for a single probability $\mathbb P(H_i\mid e),$ Bayes' rule states: $$\mathbb P(H_i\mid e) = \dfrac{\mathbb P(e\mid H_i) \cdot \mathbb P(H_i)}{\sum_k \mathbb P(e\mid H_k) \cdot \mathbb P(H_k)}$$ ## [1zj Functional form] In [1zj functional form], Bayes' rule states: $$\mathbb P(\mathbf{H}\mid e) \propto \mathbb P(e\mid \mathbf{H}) \cdot \mathbb P(\mathbf{H}).$$ The posterior probability function over hypotheses given the evidence, is *proportional* to the likelihood function from the evidence to those hypotheses, times the prior probability function over those hypotheses. Since posterior probabilities over [1rd mutually exclusive and exhaustive] possibilities must sum to $1,$ [1rk normalizing] the product of the likelihood function and prior probability function will yield the exact posterior probability function.
